header.title: Spike Lee was right to ‘storm out’ when Green Book won best picture at Oscars amid ‘white saviour’ criticism – here is why
header.postText: The biggest night in Hollywood has sparked yet another debate over race and the ‘white saviour complex’ as Green Book won best picture at the Oscars.', 'Spike Lee – who grabbed the award for best adapted screenplay for BlacKkKlsansman – reportedly ‘stormed out’ when Green Book won the award on Sunday night and I wasn’t surprised nor could I fault him for it.', 'For starters, Green Book is a biopic about a black man that focuses on a white man and like Spike, I am exhausted – and bored – of watching Hollywood pat themselves on the back for pushing a ‘black movie’ while simultaneously erasing the voices of the central characters.', 'The Oscars can and must do better.', 'In case you missed it: Green Book, which stars Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen, beat off competition from the likes of Black Panther, Bohemian Rhapsody, Roma, A Star Is Born and Spike’s own BlacKkKlansman to scoop the coveted best picture award.', 'In the midst of Black Panther and Spike’s film – both incredible projects focused on the lives of black characters – Green Book seemed like the typical choice for an Oscar win, but that doesn’t mean that the status quo isn’t a problematic annoyance.', 'Directed by Peter Farrelly, Green Book follows a white man, Tony Lip (Mortensen) who drives around an African-American pianist, Dr Don Shirley, on a concert tour in the Deep South during the 1960s.', 'Admittedly it is a ‘beautiful’ watch – considering the fact that I laughed, winced and felt extremely anxious before I could even complain about the ‘white saviour trope’.', 'On paper, the movie is a ‘good’ one and Ali – who won the award for best supporting actor – acted the heck out of his role as Don Shirley.', 'But sadly the story focused on a less accomplished cab-driving Tony, his background, his awful manners, and his very racist family.', 'Don Shirley’s extraordinary life and existence was the second act of his own story and the main star was the self-redemptive Tony, who somehow figured out how to go from being casually racist to learning how to have a singular black friend.', 'These are the things that get awards, I see.', 'It barely gave due diligence to the experience of Don, a musical genius, who at times was not allowed to dine with the people who travelled and paid to watch him perform.', 'In fact, the actual Green Books – aka Negro Travelers’ Green Book formerly known as The Negro Motorist Green Book – that the film was named after barely got a cameo, unless Tony was holding it in between scenes.', 'Rather, whenever Don had a problem – ie getting beat up by bigots – we learned about it when Tony ‘saved him’ from the situation before gifting viewers with his shallow critique on race relations in the US.', 'Despite the tears and giggles, the narrative was as shallow as a puddle in a desert because it stripped the real-life Don Shirley and African-Americans from starring in their own story.', 'This is telling as Ali collected the award for best supporting actor – surely that in itself is a red flag that something is really wrong in this supposedly post-racial society that we live in.', 'This would be a great point to mention that when I watched the film with my best friend, we were surrounded by cinemagoers in multi-cultural London who laughed hysterically at some of the most upsetting and violently racist scenes.', 'It leaves me to ask myself whether the Academy only favours black stories when told from the eyes of a white man or woman? Of course, Black Panther or Spike’s film did not have to win Best Picture, but I find it very symbolic that the Marvel film celebrated for positive portrayal of black people lost out to the biopic about a black man told by a white man.', 'Black Culture – a term I have found myself increasingly uncomfortable with – is not a monolith, so it would be impossible for me to entirely and completely understand the displeasure descendants of slaves and African-Americans felt while watching Green Book.', 'As a Black Briton of Nigerian descent, I can emphasise with Spike and I hope one day the Oscars can too.
